Wednesday, June 12, 1968
Project Radio Counterpart of PBL
As Contribution to ‘Urban Renewal’;
Needs 750G Ford Foundation Backing
Creation of a Public Radio Net¬
work, a nightly interconnect of
some 50 educational stations sim¬
ilar in concept to PBL, will be
proposed later this week to the
Ford Foundation by Jack Summer-
field, general manager of WRVR
<FM), N. Y., the Riverside Church
outlet, and Jerrold Sandler, exec
director of the National Educa¬
tional Radio division of the Na¬
tional Assn, of Educational Broad¬
casters. The proposal is the out¬
growth of a study conducted for
Ford by Summerfield and Sandler
on the feasibility of establishing
• public radio project. The non¬
commercial web would draw on
the program resources of both
NET and PBL.
Recently the Ford Foundation
committed $500,000 to the cause*
of public radio, but the money
was not allocated to any specific
project. Summerfield proposes that
Fold commit $750,000 for the
Public Radio NetWork. Foundation
is expected to decide on the pro¬
posal some fciimie in July, with
broadcast consultant Fred Friend¬
ly playing a key role in that de¬
cision.
The proposed network would
probably function as an autono¬
mous division of the National Edu¬
cational Television and Radio
Centre (NETRC), the legal, ^cor¬
porate name for what is better
known as NET. Its relation to
NETRC would be similar to that
of the Children’s Television Work¬
shop, an $8,000,000 project started
in April by the Carnegie and Ford
Foundations and the U.S. Dept,
of Health, Education and Welfare.
A national advisory committee
would not be concerned with spe¬
cifics on a daily basis. The ad¬
visory committee, whose members
will not be drawn from PBL’s
board, would also function as part
of NETRC.
A Nightly Strip
The Public Radio Network is en¬
visioned by Summerfield as a 39-
week project, starting Oct, 1, and
consisting of a nightly (Monday-
Friday) program ranging in length
from 60 to 90 minutes. The full¬
time staff, numbering about 25
people, would work out of a pro¬
duction centre in New York and a
public affairs bureau in Washing¬
ton. The series would feature a
large group of experts and com¬
mentators drawn from various
fields. Who would serve in a mam j
ner similar to the guest pundits I
on ABC-TV's nightly newscast.
Summerfield says it would not be
possible to obtain network-calibre
commentators except on a con¬
tributing basis. The practice of
employing parttime pundits is con¬
ceived as a solution to the per¬
sonnel problem—the difficulty of
attracting top-drawer journalistic
talent—that has plagued educa¬
tional radio for some time.
Summerfield says the public ra¬
dio network would build on NET
and PBL, using the same people
and in some cases the same pro¬
gramming involved in those en¬
deavors. For example, PBL chief
correspondent Edward P. Morgan
might deliver a radio commentary
several times a week, and NET
reporter Paul Niven might also be
heard. The stress would be on
news and comment with an exten¬
sive use of actualities. Series
| would have a cultural dimension,
| which could include music (though
not full-length concerts) and
drama. Summerfield says there
conceivably could be a BBC pro¬
duction from the “World Theatre”
series or an adaptation of an off-
B road way play.
Live and Interconnected
A live interconnect of about 50
stations is envisioned, including
the stations of the Eastern Educa¬
tional Radio Network. The latter
are WRVR New York, WGBH Bos¬
ton, WAMC Albany, WFCR Am¬
herst (Mass.), WAMU Washington,
WUHY Philadelphia and WRFK
Richmond. A midwestem network
of the “big 10” educational institu¬
tions in that area would expand
the coverage to a hoped-for cross¬
country reach.
The Eastern Educational Radio
Network stations had been inter¬
connected some years back but,
according to Summerfield, “tele¬
phone line - bills killed us then.”
He would like to see the FCC set
reduced rates for interconnection
of non-commercial stations so that
Ford money could be spent mostly
on programming rather than to
pay AT&T bills.
Summerfield, who will be exec
director of the Public Radio Net¬
work and exec producer of the
series, assuming Ford approval,
says he hopes for residual broad¬
cast rights to the sound portions
of PBL or NET programs when
suitable for radio rebroadcast
“Ovf matter” from the tv pro¬
grams might also be used, but the
emphasis would be on radio-only
material.
One of the problems facing the
project is achieving harmony be¬
tween the National Assn, of Edu¬
cational Broadcasters and NETRC,
which have often seemed at cross
purposes. The NAEB operates a
tape network (as opposed to a live
interconnect). Summerfield hopes
to make available some outstand¬
ing PBL, NET and public radio
programs to the NAEB tape net¬
work. He would also like to see
the tape network headquarters
shifted from the Univ. of Illinois
to Washington, D.C., and has
sought installation of new Ampex
equipment iin the Capital to set up
a tape duplication centre there.
One of the projects Summer-
field is working on for the radio
series is a national dial-in for
narcotics addicts. The concept,
similar to the currently airing
“Night Call” program, would en¬
able listeners in 50 markets to call
a central number in New York to
talk to one or more experts on
addiction, seeking advice and coun¬
sel regarding treatment.
Occasional special events pro¬
gramming would be aired in addi¬
tion to, or possibly in place of, the
regular nightly series.
Summerfield describes the pro¬
posed educational network as not
really a “renaissance of radio—
call it an urban renewal.”
Sandler, who originally was
Slated to be a part of the public
radio web, has taken a position
with a national book project. He
will be succeeded August 1 as
exec director of NER by Robert
Mott, chairman of the department
of communications and head of
radio station KWSC at Washing¬
ton State U., Pulltmian. 1
